header.title: The Hexagonal Geometry of the Tree of Life
header.category: Western Esotericism, Qabalah, Sacred Geometry, Polyhex Mathematics

central_thesis: The kabbalistic Tree of Life diagram, including its ten sefirot and twenty-two pathways, is fundamentally constructed using and uniquely linked to the geometry of the hexagon, specifically through a system termed 'polyhex mathematics'. This geometric correspondence also extends to the Hebrew alphabet, providing a visual and structural representation for esoteric principles and facilitating new forms of meditation and divination.

structure_content.summary: This treatise provides geometric correspondences for the Tree of Life through visual meditation and contemplation, building upon the author's previous work on the esoteric meaning of the Tree. It is intended for students of Kabbalah and encourages intuitive understanding through imagery.

Establishes the foundational premise that the Tree of Life diagram is constructed based on hexagonal geometry. Introduces 'polyhex mathematics' as the system by which individual sefirot and pathways are also symbolically represented by hexagonal figures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to the Polyhex Tree of Life
structure_content.summary: Defines polyhexes by the number of adjacent hexagons (monohex, dihex, trihex, tetrahex, pentahex) and correlates their unique counts (1, 1, 3, 7, 22) to the fundamental elements of the Kabbalistic Tree of Life: Ain ('Absolute Unknown'), Ain Sof (First Veil), Aur (Second Veil), 3 Highest Sefirot, 7 Lower Sefirot, and 22 Pathways.

Details the assignment of specific polyhex shapes to the components of the Tree of Life. The monohex symbolizes Ain Sof, the dihex Aur. Their combination forms the Keter trihex ('point'). The remaining trihexes represent Hockmah ('line') and Binah ('curve'). The seven tetrahexes are assigned to the lower sefirot, with Malkut's tetrahex being unique in its tiling property and resembling Binah. The Keter-Malkut relationship is further illustrated by a heptahex resembling a hexagram. The four hexagons of tetrahexes and three of trihexes are associated with the letters of the Holy Names YHVH and YHV respectively. The twenty-two pentahexes correspond to the Tree's pathways and Hebrew letters, with a special 'Shin pentahex' identified by its isohedral tiling property and geometric similarity to Binah and Malkut.

Explores the assignment of the twenty-two pentahexes to the twenty-two letters of the Hebrew alphabet. Twelve 'simple' pentahexes, geometrically distinct, are assigned to the twelve Simple Hebrew letters, grouped by astrological elements (Fire, Water, Air, Earth) and characterized by symbolic 'processes of change' (e.g., tower raising, wave breaking). This section then introduces the concept of 'Pentahex Word Forms', where pentahexes are combined to create geometric sigils for Hebrew words like YHVH, DBR, and angelic names like Michael.

structure_content.chapter_title: Constructing Polyhex Tree of Life Mandalas
structure_content.summary: Describes how the polyhexes can be assembled into various mandalas representing the Tree of Life. Two types are explored: a 34-polyhex mandala (including the primordial veils) and a 32-polyhex mandala (representing the traditional 'paths of wisdom'). The process involves arranging the first twelve polyhexes (sefirot + veils) into a central hexagon, surrounded by the twenty-two pentahexes (pathways). Mandalas include hexagonal, snowflake, and triangular forms, highlighting the total of 147 individual hexagons within the 32-polyhex designs, a number deemed significant by the author in relation to 'Jacob's Wheel'.

Outlines a practical system for meditation and divination using 32 polyhex tiles. These tiles are colored (yellow for 3-hexes, blue for 4-hexes, red for 5-hexes) and inscribed with numbers (1-10 for sefirot) and the 22 Hebrew alphabet letters (for pathways). The 1-hex and 2-hex polyhexes are excluded from divination as they represent unmanifested realms. The process involves drawing or scattering tiles like runes, and arranging them into 'word-forms' or mandalas for visual meditation on their symbolic correspondences.

key_concepts.definition: A geometric system where figures are constructed by joining hexagons adjacently. The classification of polyhexes by the number of hexagons (e.g., monohex, dihex, trihex) is directly correlated to the structural components of the Kabbalistic Tree of Life and the Hebrew alphabet.

Geometric shapes formed by 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 adjacent hexagons. Specifically, 1-hex (monohex) corresponds to Ain Sof, 2-hex (dihex) to Aur, 3-hex (trihex) to the 3 Highest Sefirot, 4-hex (tetrahex) to the 7 Lower Sefirot, and 5-hex (pentahex) to the 22 Pathways/Hebrew Letters.

Geometric arrangements of polyhex tiles that represent the Kabbalistic Tree of Life, either as a 34-polyhex mandala (including primordial veils) or a 32-polyhex mandala (representing the 10 Sefirot and 22 Pathways). These mandalas serve as tools for visual meditation.

The association of the 22 unique pentahex shapes with the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet. These 'letters' can be combined to form 'Pentahex Word Forms' (sigils) for magical operations or symbolic contemplation.

The total number of individual hexagons comprising a 32-polyhex Tree of Life mandala (9 from trihexes, 28 from tetrahexes, 110 from pentahexes). This number is identified by the author as highly significant in his esoteric investigations, particularly in relation to 'Jacob's Wheel'.

A unique pentahex among the 22 that tiles 'isohedrally' and bears geometric similarity to the Binah trihex and Malkut tetrahex. It is assigned to the Hebrew Mother letter Shin, reflecting a kabbalistic association with Binah.

practical_system.description: The practical system involves creating or obtaining 32 distinct polyhex tiles for divination and meditation. These tiles represent the 10 Sefirot and 22 Pathways of the Tree of Life, excluding the primordial veils (1-hex and 2-hex polyhexes). The tiles are categorized by their polyhex group (3-hex, 4-hex, 5-hex) and are color-coded: 3-hex tiles (Keter, Hockmah, Binah) are yellow and inscribed with numbers 1-3 (and possibly Hebrew names); 7-hex tiles (Lower Sefirot) are blue and inscribed with numbers 4-10 (and possibly Hebrew names); 22-hex tiles (Pathways) are red and inscribed with the 22 Hebrew letters. The system encourages personal inspiration for coloring and inscription.
tools: Inscriptions: Numbers (1-10) for Sefirot, Hebrew words for Sefirot, 22 Hebrew alphabet letters
Cloth bag (for drawing tiles in divination)
rituals: Divination: Polyhex tiles are placed in a cloth bag and drawn out singly, or scattered upon a flat surface in a cluster, to gain insight, akin to rune-casting. The interpretation would depend on the drawn tiles' Sefirotic or pathway correspondences and their geometric relationships to each other.

Meditation: Polyhex tiles are arranged into 'word-forms' (sigils of Hebrew words) or larger geometric mandalas (e.g., hexagonal, snowflake, triangular). The practitioner meditates upon the sefirotic and pathway correspondences represented by the shapes, colors, and arrangements during the construction process, fostering intuitive understanding and 'divine illumination'.

relevant_quotes.text: This short treatise explores (using polyhex mathematics) the special relationship that exists between the kabbalistic Tree of Life diagram and the geometry of the simple hexagon. It reveals how the ten sefirot and the twenty-two pathways of the Tree of Life are each individually and uniquely linked to the hexagonal form.
The mathematical sequence 1, 1, 3, 7, 22 is interesting because it describes the basic elements of the structure of the kabbalistic Tree of Life.
Thus, the hexagonal geometry that is used to construct the basic layout of the Tree of Life diagram is also seen to extend to its individual component parts (i.e. to the sefirot and pathways).
The kabbalistic system of the Sefer Yetzirah associates the Hebrew letter Shin with the sefirah Binah (and therefore also indirectly with the sefirah Malkut).

If we view the pentahexes as individual letters of a geometrically based alphabet then words constructed using this alphabet will assume unique shapes according to the way that their component letters are fitted together.
The thirty-two polyhexes of the 3-hex to 5-hex polyhex groups can be used practically as tools for meditation and divination.
The number 147 keeps cropping up in my esoteric investigations and appears to be very significant-particularly in relation to Jacob's Wheel.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work presents a unique and internally consistent system for understanding the Kabbalistic Tree of Life through polyhex mathematics. It offers a novel geometric lens to an established esoteric system, providing visual and structural correlations for the Sefirot and Pathways that can deepen a practitioner's intuitive understanding. The concept of 'Pentahex Word Forms' for sigilization and the application of polyhex tiles for divination connect this theoretical framework directly to operative magical practice, aligning with modern magical currents that value flexible, systematized approaches to symbol and form. It introduces a specific form of sacred geometry that could be integrated into various Hermetic, Qabalistic, or even Chaos Magic practices.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book is explicitly aimed at 'students of the Kabbalah who already have some knowledge of the kabbalistic Tree of Life.' Beyond this, it would appeal to practitioners of Western Esotericism, occultists interested in sacred geometry, geometric magic, sigilization, and new methods of divination. Its focus on visual meditation and contemplation makes it relevant for those seeking to enhance their magical and spiritual practices through symbolic and geometric engagement.
